Not true. In fact, the opposite's true. Serious analysts have said that the september numbers show that the decline is NOT due to people leaving the workforce.

Another interesting thing about the numbers is the revision upward of the July and August numbers, by nearly 30% and 50%, respectively. The revised numbers are more reliable because they're based on actual payroll data rather than business surveys. Yet you don't hear Dems accusing businesses of lying to BLS surveyers to make the numbers look worse for the Pres, even though the ADP estimates (based on its actual payroll data at the time), were, indeed, much higher than the figures reported initially. Because Dems aren't prepared to do and say anything, whether true or not, to get elected.

Serious analysts also pointed out that at least half of the difference in the size of the workforce, between 2009 and now, relates to the expected number of baby boomers retiring, starting in 2011. There are also more people in college than in 2009, and therefore out of the workforce. Maybe the stock market recovery enabled baby boomers and others who weren't expected to retire to leave the workforce.

Finally, unemployment figures have always left out those who've stopped looking for work, even under the vaunted Reagan. He even began counting the military, something that hadn't been done before, to make the numbers look better. (They're no longer included.) The method has to be the same if we want to compare figures with the past.

Mark, BLS not only reports regularly on underemployed people (http://www.bls.gov/news.release/empsit.t15.htm), but also conducts an ongoing discussion of the problem and policy solutions in its Monthly Labor Review, such as this article: bls.gov/opub/mlr/2010/11/art1exc.htm

Dave, here is the release the BLS puts out each month, which, as you can see, has links to many of the different supporting analyses and data sets: http://bls.gov/news.release/empsit.nr0.htm

This FAQ page provides clear language explanations of BLS methods and interpretation of their reporting: http://www.bls.gov/cps/cps_htgm.htm

The indexes and data collection are constructed to accurately report, through methods that have been improved over decades the employment and unemployment situation. It is a completely transparent process, peer reviewed by academic and business economists.

The other is for them to not get jobs for so long they don't count anymore. That is what happened this month. That is the only thing that has been keeping us from double digits since the last years of Bush.

The labor pool does not count the long term unemployed or those who gave up looking out of frustration and discouragement. After one year they become "long term" and are not counted, unless they drop out of job search in frustration. They are not counted as unemployed anymore. They are not employed either. They just don't count for anything.

We have a vastly increased number of people who just don't count for anything. That is what changed in this month's numbers. It is what has been keeping us from seeing the Depression we are really in since before we were rid of Bush.

I started picking pears in the deserted orchards of santa clara valley in the 1970s. I would go after the pear pickers were done with picking the commercial crop. the ground would be littered with over ripe fruit, but for a solitary picker, there were a few left on the trees. the orchards have all been pulled out to make way for computer companies and strip malls. the main crops moved to the central valley to small privately owned orchards. most private yards go for citrus, figs, and peaches rather than pears these days. Pears were brought to USA from France, where pears are revered in the culinary sense.

Pear picking is different than other fruits. the fruit does not ripen on the tree. it needs to be picked hard and then ripens from the inside out off the tree. so pears picked on the tree seemingly ripe, are already starting to over ripen and rot. so it is also okay to buy rock hard pears and let them stand on the counter to ripen, which is not often the best course of action for stone fruits and other fruits.

It's entirely possible that there are *many* older adults on the autism spectrum (especially on the milder/ moderate end) who just haven't been diagnosed. There are many more pediatric specialists involved in diagnosing autism than geriatric specialists. There is much more of a push (especially at schools) for testing and diagnosis of young children.

Just in my own family, there are least a dozen people age 50+ who are on the spectrum. (Including my mom and my grandmother, several of my great aunts and uncles, cousins, etc.) From all accounts, my great-grandfather probably had Aspergers as well. Most people didn't know anything about autism until maybe 20 years ago, so they didn't know what to look for. Older people who are high-functioning (with jobs, families, etc.) may have never thought about it, or never received a diagnosis.

There are known genetic components to autism, as well as new studies suggesting that paternal age may be a factor. There are many scientists working on autism research, and many resources being devoted to it- it's a very complex issue. I don't know what "immediate action" can really be taken at the moment. The vaccine connection is unsubstantiated nonsense and needs to stop.

The current autism rate of one in 88 comes from studies of eight year olds, not eighty year olds. No one has ever been able to show us a comparable rate among adults. That simple fact should be scaring us all.

Officially autism has no known cause or cure, There's nothing a mainstream doctor can tell a new mom so that her baby who was born healthy and is developing normally won't also end up on the autism spectrum.

All these facts should make autism a health emergency that demands immediate action.

Anne Dachel, Media editor: Age of Autism
